articles.headline: Nobel to Lessing, Incisive Voice of Women’s Fate
articles.snippet: Doris Lessing, the novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
articles.abstract: Doris Lessing, the novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doris Lessing, the Persian-born, Rhodesian-raised and London-residing novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, yesterday won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Sarah Lyall

articles.headline: Ousted Chief of Retailer Strikes Back at Directors
articles.snippet: Children’s Place, which runs the Disney Store chain, said its former C.E.O. left “at the request of the board” and described improper conduct involving “securities trades.”
articles.abstract: Children’s Place, which runs the Disney Store chain, said its former C.E.O. left “at the request of the board” and described improper conduct involving “securities trades.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When the board of Children’s Place ousted its chief executive, Ezra Dabah, several weeks ago over supposed violations of the company’s code of conduct, the clothing retailer assumed he would leave quietly.

articles.headline: Big Shake-Up as Citigroup Combines Two Key Units
articles.snippet: Citigroup said it would combine its investment banking and alternative investment units, bringing both groups together under one leader, Vikram S. Pandit.
articles.abstract: Citigroup said it would combine its investment banking and alternative investment units, bringing both groups together under one leader, Vikram S. Pandit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s embattled chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, announced a major reorganization and management shake-up last night as questions linger about his ability to run the giant bank.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In India, a $2,500 Pace Car
articles.snippet: Automakers in India, one of the world’s fastest-growing car markets, are racing to respond to Indians’ desire for small and inexpensive cars, some as cheap as $2,500.
articles.abstract: Automakers in India, one of the world’s fastest-growing car markets, are racing to respond to Indians’ desire for small and inexpensive cars, some as cheap as $2,500.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Oct. 11 — A revolution is taking place in India that could change what most of the world drives.

articles.headline: Crackdown Upends Slaughterhouse’s Work Force
articles.snippet: The federal effort to flush out illegal immigrants is having major effects on workers and employers alike.
articles.abstract: The federal effort to flush out illegal immigrants is having major effects on workers and employers alike.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAR HEEL, N.C. — Last November, immigration officials began a crackdown at Smithfield Foods’s giant slaughterhouse here, eventually arresting 21 illegal immigrants at the plant and rousting others from their trailers in the middle of the night.

articles.headline: Relations Sour Between Shiites and Iraq Militia
articles.snippet: In many Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad, the Mahdi Army is increasingly regarded as a threat.
articles.abstract: In many Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad, the Mahdi Army is increasingly regarded as a threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 11 — In a number of Shiite neighborhoods across Baghdad, residents are beginning to turn away from the Mahdi Army, the Shiite militia they once saw as their only protector against Sunni militants. Now they resent it as a band of street thugs without ideology.

articles.headline: Death Reveals Harsh Side of a ‘Model’ in Japan
articles.snippet: The starvation of a welfare recipient whose benefits were cut has turned attention to a system touted as a model.
articles.abstract: The starvation of a welfare recipient whose benefits were cut has turned attention to a system touted as a model.
articles.lead_paragraph: KITAKYUSHU, Japan — In a thin notebook discovered along with a man’s partly mummified corpse this summer was a detailed account of his last days, recording his hunger pangs, his drop in weight and, above all, his dream of eating a rice ball, a snack sold for about $1 in convenience stores across the country.

articles.headline: ABC Reshapes the Evening News for the Web
articles.snippet: Aiming to attract younger audiences, ABC is using its evening news staff to produce a separate and distinct 15-minute daily news program for the Web.
articles.abstract: Aiming to attract younger audiences, ABC is using its evening news staff to produce a separate and distinct 15-minute daily news program for the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: Huddled with a producer in an editing suite on a recent Friday afternoon, the ABC News correspondent Bill Blakemore enthusiastically helped put the finishing touches on a video account of his recent trip to Greenland to see the effects of global warming.

articles.headline: Maybe It’s Time to Restructure Executive Stock Options
articles.snippet: Two professors of management offer evidence that stock options as they are now structured act as an incentive for corporate bosses to take poor risks, with no serious consequence to themselves.
articles.abstract: Two professors of management offer evidence that stock options as they are now structured act as an incentive for corporate bosses to take poor risks, with no serious consequence to themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few decades ago, when corporate America was viewed as boring and bosses were paid only a few dozen times what ordinary people were, professors worried that executives were playing it too safe.
